text.0: fain would i win my friend to kindly friendship so may the sage come through the airs wide ocean.
text.1: remembering the earth and days to follow obtain a son the issue of his father.
text.2: thy friend loves not the friendship which considers her who is near in kindred as stranger.
text.3: sons of the mighty asura the heroes supporters of the heavens see far around them.
text.4: yea this the immortals seek of thee with longing progeny of the sole existing mortal.
text.5: then let thy soul and mine be knit together and as a loving husband take thy consort.
text.6: shall we do now what we neer did aforetime we who spake righteously now talk impurely.
text.7: gandharva in the floods the dame of waterssuch is our bond such our most lofty kinship.
text.8: even in the womb god tvaṣṭar vivifier shaping all forms creator made us consorts.
text.9: none violates his holy ordinances that we are his the heavens and earth acknowledge.
text.10: who knows that earliest day whereof thou speakest who hatb beheld it who can here declare it.
text.11: great is the law of varuṇa and mitra what wanton wilt thou say to men to tempt them.
text.12: i yami am possessed by love of yama that i may rest on the same couch beside him.
text.13: i as a wife would yield me to my husband like carwheels let us speed to meet each other.
text.14: they stand not still they never close their eyelids those sentinels of gods who wander round us.
text.15: not mego quickly wanton with another and hasten like a chariot wheel to meet him.
text.16: may sūryas eye with days and nights endow him and ever may his light spread out before him.
text.17: in heaven and earth the kindred pair commingle on yam be the unbrotherly act of yama.
text.18: sure there will come succeeding times when brothers and sisters will do acts unmeet for kinsfolk.
text.19: not me o fair oneseek another husband and make thine arm a pillow for thy consort.
text.20: is he a brother when no lord is left her is she a sister when destruction cometh.
text.21: forced by my love these many words i utter come near and hold me in thy close embraces.
text.22: i will not fold mine arms about thy body they call it sin when one comes near his sister.
text.23: not meprepare thy pleasures with another thy brother seeks not this from thee o fair one.
text.24: alas thou art indeed a weakling yama we find in thee no trace of heart or spirit.
text.25: as round the tree the woodbine clings another will cling albout thee girt as with a girdle.
text.26: embrace another yami let another even as the woodbine rings the tree enfold thee.
text.27: win thou his heart and let him win thy fancy and he shall form with thee a blest alliance.
